verses.text: Do not boast about tomorrow, for you do not know what a day may bring.
verses.comment: This verse warns against presumption and teaches humility regarding the future. James echoes this teaching, emphasizing our dependence on God’s providence.

verses.text: Let another praise you, and not your own mouth; a stranger, and not your own lips.
verses.comment: Self-exaltation is discouraged. Receiving praise from others, rather than boasting, aligns with the virtue of humility, which is critical in the Gospel's call (see Matthew 23:12).

verses.text: A stone is heavy, and sand a burden, but the irritation caused by fools is heavier than both.
verses.comment: The image emphasizes how foolishness can cause great distress. This echoes wisdom teachings on patience and long-suffering.

verses.text: Anger is cruel and wrath is like a flood, but who can stand before jealousy?
verses.comment: Jealousy is seen as more destructive than anger or wrath, highlighting the need for charity and self-control.

verses.text: Open rebuke is better than hidden love.
verses.comment: Correction given openly, yet prudently, is more valuable than love that is never expressed. This reflects the biblical ideal of fraternal correction within the communion of believers.

verses.text: Wounds from a friend can be trusted, but kisses from an enemy are deceitful.
verses.comment: True friendship sometimes involves difficult truths, while flattery can conceal malice. This foreshadows the betrayal of Christ with a kiss.

verses.text: One who is full refuses honey, but to the hungry even what is bitter tastes sweet.
verses.comment: Our spiritual appetite influences our desire for virtue and pleasure. Spiritual hunger prepares the heart for grace.

verses.text: Like a bird wandering from its nest, so is a man who wanders from his home.
verses.comment: This suggests the importance of rootedness, both in family and faith. Departure from one’s place leads to vulnerability.

verses.text: Oil and incense make the heart glad, and the sweetness of a friend comes from heartfelt counsel.
verses.comment: Fraternal counsel is compared to the joy of anointing and worship, echoing biblical themes of fellowship and spiritual guidance.

verses.text: Do not forsake your friend or your father’s friend, and do not go to your brother’s house in the day of your calamity; better is a neighbor nearby than a brother far away.
verses.comment: Faithfulness in relationships is emphasized, showing the value of local fellowship in times of need.

verses.text: Be wise, my son, and bring joy to my heart, so that I can answer those who reproach me.
verses.comment: Parental joy in a child’s wisdom echoes biblical themes of spiritual fatherhood and discipleship.

verses.text: A prudent person sees danger and hides himself, but the simple go on and suffer for it.
verses.comment: Discernment and preparation prevents harm; vigilance is a recurring wisdom theme.

verses.text: Take the garment of one who has put up security for a stranger; hold it in pledge if he has provided it for a foreign woman.
verses.comment: The text teaches caution in financial matters, a consistent wisdom warning throughout Proverbs.

verses.text: If someone loudly blesses his neighbor early in the morning, it will be taken as a curse.
verses.comment: Wisdom includes discretion and empathy in speech, avoiding annoyance even with good intentions.

verses.text: A continual dripping on a rainy day and a quarrelsome wife are alike.
verses.comment: This simile emphasizes the challenge of domestic disharmony and the biblical call to peace in the household.

verses.text: Restraining her is like restraining the wind or grasping oil with your right hand.
verses.comment: Unresolved strife is nearly impossible to contain, teaching the value of patience and reconciliation.

verses.text: Iron sharpens iron, and one man sharpens another.
verses.comment: Spiritual growth is fostered in community as believers edify each other. The principle reflects spiritual formation and accountability.

verses.text: Whoever tends a fig tree will eat its fruit, and whoever guards his master will be honored.
verses.comment: Faithful service leads to reward, echoing Christ’s teaching about stewardship and spiritual vigilance.

verses.text: As water reflects the face, so one’s heart reveals the person.
verses.comment: Outward actions flow from the heart; inner transformation is necessary for true virtue.

verses.text: Sheol and Abaddon are never satisfied, and neither are the eyes of man.
verses.comment: Unending desire, if unchecked, leads to spiritual emptiness. The passage points toward the need for detachment and contentment.

verses.text: The crucible tests silver, and the furnace tests gold, but a man is tested by the praise he receives.
verses.comment: Praise is a test of character, showing whether humility or pride rules the heart—an important spiritual lesson for leadership and ministry.

verses.text: Though you grind a fool in a mortar with pestle along with grain, his foolishness will not leave him.
verses.comment: External measures cannot change the heart without God’s grace; spiritual renewal is necessary for transformation.

verses.text: Know well the condition of your flocks, and pay attention to your herds.
verses.comment: Diligence in stewardship reflects the image of the shepherd, which Christ fulfills in the New Testament.

verses.text: For riches do not last forever, and does a crown endure through all generations?
verses.comment: Earthly wealth and even authority are fleeting, urging trust in eternal promises and spiritual inheritance.

verses.text: When the grass is gone and new growth appears, and the herbs of the mountains are gathered in,
verses.comment: Cycles of nature remind us of providence and seasonality in stewardship.

verses.text: the lambs will provide you with clothing, and the goats with the price of a field.
verses.comment: Flocks and herds meet practical needs, highlighting the importance of wise stewardship and provision.

verses.text: And you will have enough goats’ milk for your food, for the food of your household, and nourishment for your servant girls.
verses.comment: God’s provision is sufficient for all under one's care, resonating with the shepherd imagery of Psalm 23. This shepherding foreshadows spiritual care, authority, and provision—key themes in Christ’s teaching on the Church’s role.
